pr_title: Make iterators auto-closeable and fix SubqueryIterator close bug

timeline.message:
Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

timeline.bodyText: What happened to the currentIds != null check here? Before your change, the SubQueryIterator was also stopped if currentIds was null, even if the elementIterator had a next element.
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: I didn't get you here. Can you elaborate a bit?
replies.author: li-boxuan
rngcntr

replies.bodyText:
Got your question. What confused me was the sentence:

Before your change, the SubQueryIterator was also stopped if currentIds was null, even if the elementIterator had a next element.

Anyway, I removed this currentIds != null condition because it is not needed anymore. In the old logic, it is needed, because currentIds == null means cached response is used, in which case there is no timer running & no results fetched from backend.
After my changes, I moved the logic into the close() method. In that method, nothing would be done if isTimerRunning evaluates to false (note that isTimerRunning == true and currentIds != null are equivalent), so the effect remains the same.
replies.author: li-boxuan

timeline.bodyText:
Not sure: The encapsulation of all the code within an if (isTimerRunning) suggests that calling close() with an already stopped timer is also a valid operation. Does it make sense to restrict the cache update to the case where the timer is still running?
From my understanding, there should be no real difference since after the timer has stopped, currentIds should not be altered anymore. But still I would be more comfortable if the if block only encapsulates operations that are invalid if the timer is stopped.
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: In this class, isTimerRunning is not only an indicator for 'timer is running', but also for 'results are being fetched from backend in a stream'. There is no way for the situation 'timer stops but currentIds not put into cache yet' to happen. Let me know if you have a better way to handle this.
replies.author: li-boxuan

timeline.bodyText: I don't have a strong opinion on this but if the ResultSetIterator itself is a CloseableIterator, would it make sense to enforce it's inner iterator to be closeable, too?
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: I actually indeed tried that at first, but I ended up changing a lot more classes, and then I gave up and kept it like this. Not because that is undoable, but because I want to keep initial changes simple. If people think that is the better way to go, I'll do that and amend this commit.
replies.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: Understood. As I said, I'm also happy with your solution but if someone has a different oppinion, please tell 😄
replies.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: I made them auto-closeable as well. To correctly delegate Traversal.close(), I ended up refactoring/modifying many iterator classes.
replies.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText:
@rngcntr Could be great if you could describe your thoughts a little bit, why should we force to accept CloseableIterator and not just Iterator. I'm still trying to review this PR, I guess I may miss some ideas / code style / patterns / etc. begind this logic. Also, I posted my thoughts here: #2218 (comment) . I may totally be wrong because I didn't research it and didn't spend much time reviewing this PR but for some reason, I feel that we can achieve better results if we don't enforce CloseableIterator to be an input and just force CloseableIterator to be be automatically closed when the last element is read.
Going in Javadoc to java.io.Closeable, it says:

Closes this stream and releases any system resources associated with it. If the stream is already closed then invoking this method has no effect.

We do implement safe close method in SubqueryIterator and this method is automatically called when we read last element from elementIterator, so, I'm not sure why we are forcing CloseableIterator to be used everywhere even so it should be used just in a couple of places.
Could be great to hear some thoughts about it.
replies.author: porunov

timeline.message:
Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

timeline.author: porunov

replies.bodyText:
Nice idea. I think stopping the timer in the close() method still would be useful in the try-with-resources statement, or when the user quits the iteration (although I cannot think of such a case where profiling is used). I think I might let next() method call hasNext() method, which in turn calls close() method when results are exhausted.
It also comes into my mind that the current solution has a bug: when the iteration is closed before iterating is over, we shouldn't put results into the cache, since the results are probably incomplete.
replies.author: li-boxuan
porunov

timeline.message:
Fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes SubqueryIterator, LimitAdjustingIterator, and
ResultSetIterator implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

timeline.bodyText: Don't forget to cache a query when the result is empty and nobody calls hasNext or next or close.
timeline.author: porunov

replies.bodyText:
I am a bit against doing so because generally, I want to avoid running the real (and maybe costly) computation in the constructor itself, especially when nobody calls hasNext or next afterward. In this class, the iterator comes from an unfiltered iterator which intersects with otherResults. The intersection can be expensive. Thus, if nobody uses this iterator afterward, the "pre-computation" will be wasted.
That being said, in this class, we know the underlying stream is not lazy, which means in the constructor, the underlying index query already happens. Probably we want to cache all results in the constructor even if nobody uses iterator, or the iterator is used but not exhausted... However, if we don't consider the internal implementation of stream = indexSerializer.query(subQuery, tx).peek(r -> currentIds.add(r));, we should consider it as lazy and avoid eager fetching if no one calls hasNext or next IMO.
replies.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: Great points! Totally makes sense.
replies.author: porunov

timeline.message:
Make iterators auto-closeable and fix SubqueryIterator close bug

This makes a few iterators implement CloseableIterator, and makes
sure SubqueryIterator finishes properly.

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

Make iterators auto-closeable and fix SubqueryIterator close bug

Changes:

1. Make a few iterators auto-closeable. Now traversal.close() can
be delegated to SubqueryIterator.
2. Extract some logic from MultiDistinctOrderedIterator and use new
MultiDistinctUnorderedIterator when orders are not given. This
makes the code cleaner and reduces the overhead of creating &
maintaining complex data structures.
3. Make a few iterators extend CloseableAbstractIterator which in
turn leverages Guava Iterator's computeNext method. Now, these
iterators don't need to explicitly write hasNext and next.
4. Fix SubqueryIterator bug so that profiler is correctly stopped
and results can be cached appropriately.

This commit does not:

1. Make all iterators auto-closeable. It only refactors iterators on
the traversal -> SubqueryIterator chain so that traversal.close()
can be delegated.
2. Refactor all iterators using computeNext method. Some iterators have
complex internal logic thus I would like to leave them as they are
in this commit. Generally, all iterators using nextInternal method
could be rewritten using computeNext which is much cleaner and
avoids eager-computing (fetches the first result in the constructor).

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

Make iterators auto-closeable and fix SubqueryIterator close bug

Changes:

1. Make a few iterators auto-closeable. Now traversal.close() can
be delegated to SubqueryIterator.
2. Extract some logic from MultiDistinctOrderedIterator and use new
MultiDistinctUnorderedIterator when orders are not given. This
makes the code cleaner and reduces the overhead of creating &
maintaining complex data structures.
3. Make a few iterators extend CloseableAbstractIterator which in
turn leverages Guava Iterator's computeNext method. Now, these
iterators don't need to explicitly write hasNext and next.
4. Fix SubqueryIterator bug so that profiler is correctly stopped
and results can be cached appropriately.

This commit does not:

1. Make all iterators auto-closeable. It only refactors iterators on
the traversal -> SubqueryIterator chain so that traversal.close()
can be delegated.
2. Refactor all iterators using computeNext method. Some iterators have
complex internal logic thus I would like to leave them as they are
in this commit. Generally, all iterators using nextInternal method
could be rewritten using computeNext which is much cleaner and
avoids eager-computing (fetches the first result in the constructor).

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

timeline.bodyText: Nit: One should avoid calling get(index) on plain lists. My suggestion is to use an iterator, which iterates over the iterators 😁
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: That would be a bit more complicated because it requires two instance variables: a current iterator and an iterator of iterators (now we just have one int type instance variable). May I know why you think one should avoid calling get(index) on List?
replies.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: I guess that's because List isn't guaranteed to be ArrayList which supports Random Access in O(1) time. Thus, someone may for some reason pass LinkedList to the constructor of this class. If so, get operation will cost O(n) time instead of O(1) time. Making this loop to be O(n^2) time. That said, it depends on List implementation which is used here
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: I think that using a current iterator and an iterator of iterators is a more safer approach here or we can force to use ArrayList here. If we use ArrayList and not List in the constructor, the rest implementation can be the same
replies.author: porunov

replies.bodyText: Thanks @porunov, that's exactly what I wanted to point out
replies.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: However, I would prefer not to enforce ArrayList. Using an iterator over an arbitrary list should be equally es fast but maintains more flexibility. Especially in case we decide to switch back to List for some reason in the future.
replies.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: @rngcntr Agree with your points. Using iterator will have more sense here.
replies.author: porunov

timeline.author: rngcntr

timeline.bodyText:
Just an idea: For large sets it can be quite inefficient to perform this check, because hash sets are not cache friendly at all. So before this check, one could query a bloom filter. If the filter says that this element is new, the check can be skipped.
On the downside, we would still need to collect the elements in allElements so insertions would still consume as much time as before. Therefore I'm not sure how significant a change like this would be.
This is just a general consideration and has nothing to do with your PR. So feel free to dismiss it 😄
timeline.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: Sounds interesting. My intuition is that would be even slower, but worth giving it a try. If I got some time I'll do some experiments and probably open up a new issue.
replies.author: li-boxuan
porunov

replies.bodyText: @porunov With your idea implemented, I'm now pretty sure a bloom filter would just cause overhead here. Even with one, either contains or add would be called anyway, so I don't see an improvement there anymore.
replies.author: rngcntr

timeline.message:
Make iterators auto-closeable and fix SubqueryIterator close bug

Changes:

1. Make a few iterators auto-closeable. Now traversal.close() can
be delegated to SubqueryIterator.
2. Extract some logic from MultiDistinctOrderedIterator and use new
MultiDistinctUnorderedIterator when orders are not given. This
makes the code cleaner and reduces the overhead of creating &
maintaining complex data structures.
3. Make a few iterators extend CloseableAbstractIterator which in
turn leverages Guava Iterator's computeNext method. Now, these
iterators don't need to explicitly write hasNext and next.
4. Fix SubqueryIterator bug so that profiler is correctly stopped
and results can be cached appropriately.

This commit does not:

1. Make all iterators auto-closeable. It only refactors iterators on
the traversal -> SubqueryIterator chain so that traversal.close()
can be delegated.
2. Refactor all iterators using computeNext method. Some iterators have
complex internal logic thus I would like to leave them as they are
in this commit. Generally, all iterators using nextInternal method
could be rewritten using computeNext which is much cleaner and
avoids eager-computing (fetches the first result in the constructor).

Fixes #2217

Signed-off-by: Boxuan Li <liboxuan@connect.hku.hk>

timeline.bodyText: I've seen you used IteratorUtils.concat(iterators);. Will it be easier to manage MultiIterator with IteratorUtils.concat(iterators); or did you create it for some other purposes (like better performance, less overhead or something like that)?
timeline.author: porunov

replies.author: li-boxuan
porunov
